dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PARTY. ROCK MUSIC BLARES. DRUNK TEENS dance around BURN BARRELS. GROUPS lounge on ratty couches and turned over b skulling cans, making out, talking shit. A BOY, 17, light MOLOTOV COCKTAIL and hurls it off the roof. Luba and Raya join THREE GUYS. ONE of them pisses onto a cloth, stuffs it in a bottle, and tries to light it. It FIZZLES. Everybody bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ammonia, not alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Drunk) You're so smart. I love you! He lunges in for a kiss, but she dodges him, laughing. Lu gives him the finger, pulling Raya toward the dancing int TEEN MAYHEM: Raya lets herself go. She gets lost in... A WHIRL of drunk and happy teens. It's tribal. They dance silhouetted against the fire and the black sky, their bac to the run-down Soviet buildings... Tonight, they don't w to think about what life holds in store. Raya stops. Dizzy. She looks at her watch, suddenly aware the time. Yelling over to Luba...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get home. Mama's gonna kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're staying with me tonight. Roman wants us there at 9 in the morning. Raya looks at Luba. Torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a few months working in a hotel. You want to work at Copyshack like your mother? Marry one of these assholes? There's nothing here!.. He said it was both of us or no go! Raya sighs, wanting to, but unable to agree. Luba hesitat she needs this so badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck your mom! But Raya shakes her head, eyes apologetic. She pushes pas Luba who watches her disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya tiptoes through a modest apartment when.... The ligh come on. Raya turns back to see HALYNA, 35. Her face torn between anger and relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm late. I tried to leave, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three in the morning. Halyna shakes her head, disappointed. Then turns off the lights. Raya stands alone as Halyna goes into her bedroom SLAM. Raya looks around the apartment, it's poverty, it's measly aspirations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver mist of dawn rises over the Golden Domes of Ky

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya sits on a stool before a WHITE WALL. Luba smokes a cigarette. ROMAN, 40, smiley, fixes a camera to a tripod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big smile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luba reads a SWISS HOTEL BROCHURE, then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (practicing) I am Natalya Verbova. I am going to Budapest to buy carpets for re- selling. I am staying two days... Raya sees ZENIA, 30, peeking in the door. Raya smiles. Ze nods, demure. Roman looks through the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one's gonna believe we really did it! Luba beams at Raya, who can't hide her own excitement. CAMERA POV: Raya looks into the camera. Her face lights u with hope... FLASH... The IMAGE FREEZES... We BURN TO WHI Then the title of the film fades in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLASHLIGHT cuts across...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE OFFICER LEEDS scans the side of a house. Rounding

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT PORCH
dialogues.text: He shakes his head at his partner, KATHRYN BOLKOVAC, 38. Earthy and athletic. She is in great shape, but her eyes of a life fully lived. She's looking at a HUSBAND and WIF standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just got a bit heated, you know how it gets. I'll apologize to the neighbors tomorrow. Kathy nods, humoring. A police radio BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to go? Kathy eyes the wife, tries to see past them into the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure everything is alright, Ma'am? The wife is still. Kathy eyes her, gently. Then, calm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. It was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The husband shifts his weight. Kathy flits a look behind noticing... Jackets hanging from the wall. Her gaze lower a hook hanging much lower than the rest of the jackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all have any children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. The wife looks down. The man stirs, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if that's all Officer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to take a quick walk through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that without a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I can, Sir, please step aside. The wife moves out of the way. The man panics. Leeds head the porch. Kathy steps over the threshold. When...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not coming in my house! He blocks her, but Kathy pushes past him, and then he... GRABS Kathy. HURLS her into a wall. CRACK. Kathy yells in EXTREME PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three POLICE OFFICERS linger. They peek through a door at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy. She sits up on a gurney. The DOCTOR examines her shoulder. It's BRUISED PURPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painful there? Kathy winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN HAWK, 50s, African American, walks in, noticing h exposed shoulders, and turns, uncomfortable. Kathy covers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm her Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her collar bone is broken. And I'm going to have to set her arm in a cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookin' for a route to the desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm gonna break every bone in my body until I'm captain. Hawk laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm sure you have a hotter date than this tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just when my self esteem was gettin' so healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found a boy locked in the basement. Badly beaten. We charged the husband with domestic assault. You made the right call. But you should've waited for backup. (sighing)... I wish I didn't have to say this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're giving Deke the gold shield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to Kathy. He has seniority. Kathy shakes her head, deeply disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deserve the promotion. You should be a detective and if we had more openings--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gold shield was the first one in four years... Sir... I'm going to have to resign, and take that position overseas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's a mistake. I want you on my team. Kathy sighs, touched. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, I'm nearly forty. I can't be on the streets much longer. Not if I don't know there's something on the other end. She looks up at Hawk, but he's staring past her at... The door. Kathy turns, seeing... A young, scared GIRL, 15 This is ERIN. Kathy's daughter. She's heard everything. H eyes Erin, sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think about it, will you? He leaves, passing Erin, who pushes down tears. Kathy eye Erin, full of love, but not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin stares out the window. Kathy watches her, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you could stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Erin turns. Serious. Weighing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's fine living at dad's, but... Now I really won't see you for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing this for us. If I have a better job, I can give you guys more. Erin nods, tearing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you have to decide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here. Erin moves over, hesitant. Kathy pulls her in to a hug, wincing slightly in pain. But keeps a brave face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure it's not dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. It's been four years. Things are getting back to normal over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOMBED OUT building, sprayed with RED GRAFFITI. DEBRIS everywhere. Torn clothes. A SIGN. Cyrillic letters: SARAJEVO - 3 KM. Sprayed across it in red: TURN AROUND!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SILHOUETTE breaks the horizon and SPEEDS towards us, throwing up gravel: a dented white BUS, emblazoned with l black letters: "UN". A UNITED STATES flag on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits in a bus full of BLUE BERETS. She looks out th window, her eyes drinking it all in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come here today as a beacon of hope, as representatives of humanity's highest aspirations. In the opposite direction, a U.S. MILITARY TANK ROLLS pas SOLDIER looks out from the HATCH. Kathy turns to see the only other woman on the bus, Carme 20s, Latina. She smiles cheekily, giving Kathy the `peace sign. Kathy smiles. IMMEDIATE SOLIDARITY. In the opposite direction, two other UN BUSES pass, one flanked by a CANADIAN FLAG, the other with a FRENCH TRICO The bus cranks around the corner, entering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final stretch into Sarajevo. Famous from so many war reports, site of many deaths. The broad, pock-marked aven is barren. SHELLED HIGH RISES lean like hungry faces, gou from their once-solid structures. Living rooms are expose the elements, wallpaper blowing in the wind like torn ski

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BUS: Carmen taps Kathy, pointing out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sniper Alley. See, the bullet marks are at eye level. People just running to the store. All the walls are splattered at head level. Kathy is over by the stark reality of war. Worse than she ever imagined

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE ALONG rapt faces... YOUNG MEN, MIDDLE-AGED MEN, head held high, ready for anything. We're in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL HYNES paces before the assembled NEW RECRUITS. He's his 50s, distinguished and seemingly in charge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been hired by Dyncorp Aerospace International to represent the US as monitors for the United Nations, which means you are the only national contingent coming from a private military. So you people chose to come here. And for the next few weeks, we will teach you how to protect the rule of law in a war zone, how to rebuild a civil society brick by brick... MOVING OVER more RECRUITS... On their laps, "DYNCORP" ORIENTATION FOLDERS. MEN, listening, determined...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and RECRUITS receive TRAINING from a PAKISTANI MONI shadowing him as he hands food-packs to a LINE of REFUGEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to ensure the dignity, equality, and inalienable human rights of every single person in this devastated place. The refugees turn their haunted eyes to the fresh faces o the NEW RECRUITS. Kathy extends a parcel to an OLD MAN. H hesitates. Then she sees... He has no arms. She's unsure to do. A young boy takes the package, leading his grandfa away. Kathy stands: WHERE AM I? ASSEMBLY HALL: Bill Hynes stands before a map of the Balk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dayton Peace Accords of 1995 ended this war, dictating that an International Police Task Force - YOU - would smooth the transition from war to peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and THREE NEW RECRUITS are led down a path along a mountainside. They move toward an UNDERGROUND BUNKER. CHILDREN play at the edge of an overgrown field. A BOY hops up on a post, about to jump over, when the lea TODD MYERS, 30s, a seasoned pro, YELLS at him, points out A sign closer to the BARBED WIRE, fringing the field... A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you will learn that peace is harder won than war.. Kathy watches the boy run back up the road. The recruits down STEEP STEPS into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light sneaks through cracks, catching on the oil black barrels of THOUSANDS of GUNS. Todd hands out BINDERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are still in the process of disarming the Muslim, Croat, and Serb militias. You will be cataloguing these arms for decommissioning records. Kathy eyes the unending stash of GUNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy drives past a MILITARY BASE, an ITALIAN FLAG flying A few hundred yards up the street, a BAR...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA LUNA BAR
dialogues.text: Driving past a another BAR. GERMAN FLAG... A SIGN: BERLIN NIGHTS... Kathy passes by, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and Carmen are led by a MONITOR through a sparsely furnished UNIT. A poster of `Born in the USA' on the wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will learn that every morning's hope... Carmen bounces her butt up and down to test her mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy inspects items on the shelves. Nothing familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cluster of WOMEN in BLACK BURKAS. They sway like reeds the wind, grief overcoming them as they watch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is haunted by yesterday's nightmare... UN BLUE HELMETS supervise the dig of a mass grave. Bodies revealed. A child's shoe is uncovered. A BURLY PEACEKEEPE turns, sickened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus arrives. The base is surrounded by barbed wire an overlook sights, manned by ARMED MILITARY. MEETING HALL: Hynes looks out at the new batch. Proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But today is a new day. As Head of the United Nations Mission here I trust that we stake our highest values, even our lives, on the belief that we can rebuild, we must renew, we will witness the rebirth of this country. The recruits are hyped, the rhetoric is working. MOVING O THEM, MAN by MAN, we REVEAL in the back: Kathy. In her crisp navy blue IPTF flack jacket. Her blon hair makes her stand out. She is one of the only women in room. Her eyes ablaze. She is completely fired up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits at the table spreading stuff on dark bread. Ca across from her. Kathy takes a bite and grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was peanut butter but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ass paste? I know. I bought it too. Let's get out of here. I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCK MUSIC ECHOES from several bars. Carmen heads toward when an AMERICAN IPTF MONITOR stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a military Bar. You want the party in there... He points to BIG NEON SIGN: THE INTERNATIONAL BAR. Tiki lights illuminate a broad patio. A PIG roasts on a spit. Kathy follows Carmen through DOZENS of off-duty IPTF, SFO and UN workers who drink and trade stories with machismo. There's a palpable sexual tension in the air. BOSNIAN WAITRESSES flirt with OFFICERS. Guys paw GIRLS with trays

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck me, we're outnumbered. Good odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hon, they're all yours. They make their way through the crowded bar, feeling the officers' double-takes. Carmen smiles coyly at Kathy, the zeroes in on JAN VAN DER VELDE, 35, handsome. He is surrounded by a group of IPTF with Dutch flags on their shoulders. Carmen throws her arms around them, jovial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine, if you insist. Mine's a Jaegermeister. Jan laughs at Carmen's forwardness, his eye on Kathy. But spots Todd Myers across the bar, and is on her way, when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you? You don't have an order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm the polite one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like polite. Carmen turns his head toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be the drunk one. Let's get toasted. Kathy smiles, a little too old for this game. Carmen lean into Kathy's ear. She smiles, and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Kathy moves to Todd and the Americans, catching Todd's ey but is distracted by a WAITRESS writhing on an ITALIAN SOLDIER's lap. The Waitress darts Kathy a look, contemptu And the soldiers notice. One leers at Kathy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd pay double for a woman in uniform. Kathy looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry pal, I'm not for sale. The Soldier is stung. The Italians laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Dyncorp. We're all for sale... Kathy, right? Todd puts his arm around Kathy, bringing her to a TABLE O AMERICAN IPTF. They greet her, friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look the basic lay of the land is we have to work with the other nationals, but we don't mix with them at night. JIM HIGGINS, 25, and even younger looking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky those wops don't carry guns or we'd've had ourselves a situation. Fucking unarmed mission. I was hoping we'd get to squeeze some off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At who? Better odds you'll step on a land mine and what the hell's a gun gonna do for you then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I'd kill the fucker who buried it. Everyone laughs. Todd turns to Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever had to take someone down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just once. The others see she's the real deal. Kathy feels good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy moves through the now-hopping bar. She's ready to leave. She searches for... Carmen. She's IN A CORNER. Sti with the group of DUTCH OFFICERS. Kathy approaches, concerned, when Jan cuts her off. He's watching Carmen, who's teetering, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should probably get her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably shouldn't have let her drink that much. Kathy moves past him, irritated. But he grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I... don't worry. I know those guys. Nothing was going to happen to her. Kathy shrugs, it doesn't mean much to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I did. And now we're both leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early sun breaks through the fog over the valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy tries to work the Bosnian coffee maker, a confusing relic. Carmen comes in, holding her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened last night? Kathy smiles, pouring her a cup of the tar-like brew. The both look at it, a little scared. Kathy eyes the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move. We're gonna be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Industrial plants dominate the skyline of this Sarajevo suburb. Kathy drives frantically past bombed-out building Carmen studies a map beside her. They hit A RED LIGHT. An stop. A GROUP OF MUSLIM WOMEN cross the street. One quest Kathy with a lingering gaze. Carmen stares at her map...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea where we are? Kathy shakes her head. No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down prefab office, with dated 80s equipment. A cou of small offices off the open center. Kathy and Carmen rush in. An IPTF OFFICER stands waiting them... Jan Van Der Velde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late night ladies? They eye him, embarrassed. He hands them each a thick bin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your duty officer. You check the duty roster. Every day. You're each assigned to monitor and instruct a group of Bosnian local police. We work in six week shifts. You instruct in the mornings, then go into the field with them in the afternoon. One of you needs to go now. He eyes an eager Kathy. Carmen shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're waiting at the 5th canton. Out the gate, then left, left, park, right... Kathy rushes off, then stops. Jan tosses a set of keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My van. There's a map in front. She drops the keys, grabs them, and rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SCHOOL sprayed with GRAFFITI and BULLETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abandoned CLASSROOM. Shabby corkboards with yellowing posters, ragged kids' drawings, and tired sticky tape. Kathy skims through the training binders. The DOOR OPENS a GROUP OF LOCAL POLICE file in. They whisper, exchanging lascivious glances. Kathy straightens her uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel free to sit wherever you like. Kathy waits for them to take their seats. They don't. A BOSNIAN WOMAN, pretty, rushes in. Spotting Kathy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I am late. I'm your interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, well... I just asked them to sit. The interpreter shakes her head benignly. They take their seats. The interpreter looks at Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They like to be difficult. They understand if you're clear. Mostly they have trouble speaking English. But let's see if you can get them to talk at all. Kathy looks out, suddenly daunted. She presses on, openin her binder as authoritatively as she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm going to be talking about crime scene investigation today. If we could-- An older officer, DANIK, stands, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we sign to say we came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, you sign the attendance at the end of the session. It's a UN mandate--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or we sign now? Full of malice. Kathy puts the sheet away, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sign later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop scoffs, and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stands in front of a BLACKBOARD with DRAWINGS on a CRIME SCENE. She crosses off TWO AREAS on the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Keeping the crime scene clean is number one. A weak smile. Nothing from the crowd. She trundles on.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember you could be           Pamyatayte scho vu bu mho stepping on the very evidence   stavatu na scho nam pokaz that could incriminate. You     yaka bula nespodivanka. T have to track anything you      vcyo datu v torbu. bag. We call that 'chain of evidence.' Kathy looks out. The cops are barely paying attention. ON stubs out a cigarette. Another closes the binder, defiant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sign sheet now? Kathy leans back, disappointed. She hands him the sheet. all sign, apathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will tell UN we were cooperating? Kathy tries to retain a poker face but their indifference stings. And just as they're about to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go to the hospital together. The cops eye her, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy's SUV pulls up behind the cluster of local police c IPTF OFFICER CLARKSON stands outside. He eyes his watch. Kathy rushes to him, but he's already a foot in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got here as quick as we could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just try to get them here on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarkson leads Kathy and the BOSNIAN POLICE through the h Gurney's and IVs suggest it's a hospital, but you wouldn' want to be examined here. Some windows are still covered wood slats, and paint barely covers old bullet holes. The floors still hold the stains of old blood. Clarkson grabs a file, and speaks without looking back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems we have two stabbings, one shooting, and a man with a broken leg and a bad hangover who can't remember what happened... Average night back in Brighton. The cops stare at him, lost. As they file into a SMALL RO filled with tightly drawn curtains. They all squeeze into center together. Kathy is pressed against the large cop. Clarkson pulls back a curtain, revealing... ZLATA SEHIK, 40, Muslim. Her face is covered with wounds. avoids the gaze of the police who stare with contempt. Sh pulls her bed-sheet up to her chin as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading chart) "facial contusions from repeated beatings with fist", "lacerations on the eye caused by the edge of an iron"... He pauses. Looking at Zlata, he moves her sheet up to exp her leg. Zlata's eyes tear. Clarkson reads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The right hand was the first entry point of a large kitchen knife"... "The second entry point in the upper left thigh"... It went through her hand and into her leg... Who's going to take this report? Kathy looks out at the Bosnian cops, but they stare at th ground. One cop peeks into the next cubicle. Kathy looks Clarkson for a cue. He holds out the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone? No answer. Clarkson looks to Kathy to take control. She t to her group, but they have even less respect for her. Sh goes to speak, when... VIKO, 25, looks up, hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will take it. The cops turn. Clarkson unclicks his pen. Viko sees Kathy hungry for support. But Danik scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (At Zlata) Tze ye yiyiy vuna. Zlata's face tightens. Viko turns to Danik, angry.... Kat looks to Clarkson, who gives her nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is Muslim. He said she deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, that's it. Everyone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Clarkson) Isn't she filing a complaint? The other cops eye Kathy, defiant. This is our turf. Clarkson ushers the cops out. Kathy catches Viko's eye. Simpatico. Then follows the other out. Kathy looks back a Zlata, who lies helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarkson leads the group. Kathy pushes up toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has to file a complaint. A woman gets stabbed in the face and there are no repercussions? Clarkson pulls Kathy aside. Viko stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit it! You hear me? Kathy reddens. The local cops look over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not investigators. We are monitors. You don't know a Serb from a Croat or a Bosniak. You've got ethnic hatreds that started a war. This isn't just policing, it's diplomacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy blushes, feeling like a chastened schoolgirl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't run the show, we make sure the show runs smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits up in bed reading from her Dyncorp/UN manual. flicks, not finding what she's looking for. Carmen comes of her room, dolled up for the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out. You can't solve this tonight. I'm not taking no for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy has dinner with Carmen, who talks away. Kathy watch the world go by. She notices an OLDER, LARGE IPTF MONITOR walking with his arm around a YOUNG GIRL, 16, dressed in short skirt. Kathy turns back to Carmen who is still talk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chanting echoes from the SINANOVA HOUSE of the Dervish Or

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viko comes in, scanning over IPTF MONITORS. Spotting Kath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viko lays down a pile of files. Zlata's picture on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zlata Sehik has been to the hospital eight time because of her husband. Every time she try to file a complaint, my bosses send her back. They always laugh at the woman... They laughed at my mother. They do not make prosecutions of domestic violence. I want to get enough evidence to do this. Kathy isn't sure. She looks around, almost guiltily...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is why you are here, no? Kathy looks at him, struck by the truth of this. She take the files, flipping through them. Thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With no police reports?.. Maybe, if you go back to the hospital... You can pull the records for every one of her visits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATOR, who hands Viko a stack of files

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits in a UN SUV. Viko watches as she goes through Zlata's hospital files. She's encouraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now get the same thing from all the doctors who treated her. They will have to testify on Zlata's behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viko and Kathy sit behind a pile of Legal Books. Viko sho Kathy a page, a questioning look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good. Let's cross reference each injury with other cases where felony assaults were ruled. Can you get something like that? Viko turns to see a LIBRARIAN at the main desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Because if stabbing someone in a bar is illegal then the same standard can be applied to a domestic assault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viko sits behind Zlata and COUNSEL while a JUDGE rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If an attorney presents this properly, referencing international standards, you might be able to get a conviction. Viko and Zlata wait... then breathe relief. They won. Vik turns TO THE BACK OF THE COURTROOM: Kathy smiles, at last feeling they can really accomplish something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy comes inside, interrupting Jan and FRANZ, Dutch IPT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, you wanted to see me? Franz excuses himself, eyeing a tense Kathy. Jan closes t door behind Franz, turning to Kathy. All business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine Rees wants to see you. Head of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's fine. You followed protocol, right? Kathy rushes out, worried. Jan smiles, in on a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits alone in the office. Degrees, plaques, and awa cover the walls. Pictures of Madeleine Rees with Kofi Ann Bill Clinton, Nelson Mandela... Kathy is intimidated. MADELEINE REES, 50s, tall, commanding, short blonde hair, British. She sashays in with a DOBERMAN on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind Helen, she's a total sap. Kathy eyes the malevolent hound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Rees, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine. You've been stirring things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this about Zlata Sehik? If I've overstepped protocol--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done in two months, what we've been trying to do for years. Madeleine sits. Kathy straightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All due respect to Viko Mezovic, but you just facilitated the first conviction for domestic abuse in Bosnian history. I'm bloody impressed. So is the Dutch Duty Officer who recommended you. Kathy takes it in. Madeleine looks out the window at TWO GLASS TOWERS that punctuate Sarajevo's skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IPTF has a Gender Affairs Office at Mission Headquarters. Dervla Hughes, the current head, is leaving and I think you're the right person to take over. Kathy is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be overseeing 12 regional offices. Any gender reports come through you. This involves anything from equality training to domestic and child abuse cases, fallout from war crimes against women, prostitution. Women in Bosnia are treated like second class citizens. You could have a real impact on their lives. What do you think? Are you interested? This is everything Kathy came to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy paces, phone to her ear. Her suitcase open, she's packing at the same time. Carmen helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know hon, it's very exciting. If this works out. It's a real opportunity for the future, but it means I have to, I have to extend my contract for another six months... Hello?.. Kathy stops pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Erin? Kathy pulls the phone close, listening. Carmen eyes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I didn't. I'll look right now. Kathy goes over to a computer, clicking open an EMAIL. ON SCREEN: A PICTURE OF ERIN in a PROM DRESS. Kathy sits bac flushed with emotion. Her enthusiasm complicated by the realization of what she's missing back home. Softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmen helps Kathy load boxes and suitcases into an SUV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe they're moving you into the city. I'm so jealous. So where's your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mission Headquarters... UNMHQ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Madeleine is UNHCHR, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I know. I don't even know if I'm still IPTF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't give an F.U.C.K. All I know is I'm gonna miss you. Stay in touch with the little people! They hug. Kathy smiles, and hops into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy drives into the CITY CENTRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy puts the last box down. She steps out onto the balc Looks out at Sarajevo, city of survivors, her new home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Member nations' flags slap in the wind. Hundreds of UN SU Kathy drives up. She takes in the huge building. Almost i disbelief that she's part of it, at the center of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The modern lobby buzzes with UN OFFICIALS and DIPLOMATS. Kathy follows RICK JONES, 30s, athletic, crisp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to have an American in the mix. You'll be reporting to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I, I thought I was reporting to Madeleine Rees' Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a joint office. She's Human Rights. But you're Police Task Force. So you go through me. But we all report to Bill Hynes anyhow. They walk through two large doors into... The Inner Sanct

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Kathy round a corner to a medium-sized office, b everywhere. Rick eyes the... mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, your ah... predecessor's files... We're waiting for Archives to get those out of here. I'll put another call in. Kathy nods, taking in the disarray. Dust sits on the stac of boxes, on papers and files strewn about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Thanks for the tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I'll leave you to it. Good luck. He leaves her. Kathy runs her eye over the place. The rea of her office less exalted than she imagined. But she's raring to go. She eyes a name plate: KATHRYN BOLKOVAC - HEAD OF GENDER AFFAIRS. Kathy stands in her office doorway, glancing up the hall. THE HALL is empty. The EXIT door at the end swings shut i the flickering fluorescent light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OLD TOWN TURKISH QUARTER
dialogues.text: Black cobbles. Merchants line the narrow pathways. Open- doored cafes serve coffee to UNEMPLOYED YOUTH. Kathy and walk along. He's delighted. She's restrained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering when you'd ask me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a date... No, seriously. It's not. I know you had a lot to do with my promotion, so I wanted to thank you. He grabs her by the hand, ducking into a SMALL ARCHWAY. A NARROW PASSAGE opens up onto a charming restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and Jan sit at a table, watching a WAITRESS put dow carraffe of wine and 'Cevapcici' (lamb dish).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to not dating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I'm not joking around. You're a nice guy. But I... The waitress reaches across Kathy with a plate. Winks at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are certain you have everything you need? The waitress eyes him coyly. Kathy studies the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fine thank you. The waitress leaves. Kathy shakes her head, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were saying I'm a nice guy-- Kathy is watching the waitress hit up another table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be in heaven over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war left behind a lot of widows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't find that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find it uncomfortable. A lot of guys don't. I don't know what else to say about it. Now finish your sentence, I'm a nice guy but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't afford to mess this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only dinner. How bad can it get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask my two ex-husbands. He grins. Kathy looks at him, unsettled by the chemistry between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick introduces Kathy to various IPTF and UN colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stacks unpacked boxes out of the way. She organizes BIG BULLETIN BOARD into 12 CANTONS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy follows an IPTF monitor, BARRY, 30s, Irish past the front of a UN BUS. A DOZEN MUSLIM WOMEN disembark and loo up, their hands over their mouths, keening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first time they've seen their homes in years. IPTF MONITORS help with unloading battered suitcases and belongings. THREE carry a couch up the steps of a buildin a YOUNG BROTHER and SISTER watch. Standing back, an ELDER WOMAN weeps in disbelief as the monitors lay final touche makeshift storm windows on her aparment. Kathy watches, Barry by her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all widows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they were so frightened to come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't believe they'd be safe. That what happened before wouldn't happen again. Except now with nobody to protect them. Kathy shakes her head. The women enter the building, thei past lives in shards at their feet. One WOMAN, 40s, stand numb, a bundle of books in her arms, tears running down h face, as her TEENAGE SON beckons her to come in the DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought helping refugees get home would be one of the best parts of the job. But it's so hard for them. Kathy nods, moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking me through this. Fill me in when you're done, and I'll send my report to Rick Jones. Another FIELD OFFICER rushes up. An urgent look on his fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field officer leads Barry and Kathy round a corner, t A YOUNG GIRL nearly passed out on the couch. Her face blo and swollen. Kathy runs up to the girl, who can barely si up. Softly waking her. The girl comes to, taking in her surroundings, and... JUMPS UP. An unmistakable look in her eyes. TERROR. Kathy eyes the field worker. He shrugs, lost. Kathy turns back to the girl, and slowly places a hand on her shoulde The girl flinches, then inches back... shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, it's-- But the girl holds out her hands, stopping Kathy. She loo around, completely disoriented. Desperately searching for exit. She eyes them all, realizing she's surrounded and then... SHE WAILS. Losing control. Slapping at all of them. Kathy moves to h trying -- gently -- to hold her tight. The girl sobs. Hopelessness in her eyes. And then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She faints. Kathy and Barry bend to catch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at field worker) Call a medic! He rushes off. Kathy and Barry lay the girl down. She lie the ground, breathing slowly, looking close to death. Kathy holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found her out in the woods. She was speaking, I don't know, she's not local. I think she's one of the girls from the bars. Looking at the girl, Kathy pushes a strand of hair from h face. And as we stay a moment longer, we realize this is. Raya. A long way from home. But then... THE DOORS OPEN. A frantic HUMAN RIGHTS WORKER carries IRK 17, into the room. Her clothes torn, her body and face bruised. Kathy looks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was further back in the woods. Irka sees Raya. Sudden relief. Then realizing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florida Bar... Ciysh... Six girl there... Iy Policai... Kathy looks to Barry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bar in the hills. Kathy shakes her head. She looks at Raya and Irka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take them to the women's shelter at Zenica. Kathy rummages through her files, catching up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Good. I'll follow up at the bar. Barry shrugs. Kathy's mind is racing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where exactly is this bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy drives up a winding mountain road, checking directi on a hand-drawn map. A LOCAL POLICE CAR swerves by in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy's SUV throws up gravel. Out her windscreen, she see THE FLORIDA BAR: A dilapidated two story building, painte garish pink. Crude palm trees painted on the side. Kathy jumps out of her SUV, and moves towards... LOCAL POLICE smoke by POLICE CARS. A LOCAL COP leads a CLUSTER of YOUNG WOMEN out the door. blink in the glaring light, pale, out of place, lost... At the end of the line, is Luba. Her eyes darting between Kathy and the Local Cops, helpless. Kathy rushes towards the cop. He eyes her, dubious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xo brovnic ce klety scey forzcic nay. He moves past her, with the Girls in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. Where are the IPTF monitoring this raid? SHOUTING ECHOES from inside the bar. TWO COPS drag out TA ZRAVBIC, 50s. He sees Kathy's uniform and SHOUTS at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zra slobovik brvicetic revic barziny Traba! Motherfockers! The cops SHOVE Tanjo in a car, and SLAM the door. Kathy t to the Local Cop, standing with the group of girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the owner? Are you taking him into custody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xivy slovic drinjnislava porslivky. Kathy looks around, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a translator on the scene? Translator?... Wait. He stops, impatient. Kathy pulls out her WALKIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Kathy Bolkovac. I need an Interpreter. At the Florida Bar. The Local Cops watch her. Kathy's eyes rest on the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I need a time and date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible. We need advance notice for field calls. The Local Cop talks at the girls. They don't understand h but his tone is clear: total disrespect. Kathy moves towa them, protectively, then sees... TWO UN SUVs parked on the other side of the bar. TWO IPTF MONITORS emerge from the bar. Kathy approaches t They seem surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I'm from Gender Affairs. I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Fred Murray. He shakes her hand. Tanjo BANGS on the window, inside the police car, apoplep with rage. Kathy glances over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the owner? (off Fred's nod) I tried to get an interpreter but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... that's fine. We're pretty much done here anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Okay. But there's... We just had two girls come in to a Human Rights Office, saying they escaped from this place. Fred seems confused. Kathy pulls out a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Local police have been watching the place for a while. This whole thing happened pretty fast. I guess those girls must've run for it. Kathy looks over as the girls are put into a van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the girls in our field office seemed pretty scared. I should follow up with these ones. The Local Cops start to move, stubbing out cigarettes, getting in cars. The Local Cop shuts the doors of the van

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see where they're taking them, but I can't intervene. You know the drill. He shrugs and smiles. Kathy hears the POLICE VAN's engine start. Turning to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll look out for your report. She rushes after the van. Fred eyes Kathy confer with the driver. He and the other Monitor, drive off. Kathy is left alone in the silence. She turns to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy moves inside. The place is rank and dingy. A small stage with a POLE in the centre. Tables fanned out around CUT WIRES hang over the stage.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR AREA
dialogues.text: Is filled with PHOTOS: YOUNG GIRLS in various poses with IPTF SOLDIERS. They range from the illicit to the obscene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stops on a photo of a NAKED GIRL on stage holding t two open wires over her head. Behind her, SOLDIERS applau Kathy takes down the photo, horrified. Turns it over. Scrawled in marker: SARAJEVO FIRECRACKER! She turns to the stage. Plugs in one of the wires. A HUZZ electricity. Tiny sparks fly. She turns, and under the bar sees... A SAFE, SMASHED OPEN handful of U.S. bills scattered about. And... PASSPORTS. Romanian, Ukrainian, Polish. All for young gir She gathers them, surprised, and stuffs them into her fil Her eyes are drawn to a back wall. She stops at a panelle door. And pushes. It opens onto... STEPS: She shines her flashlight up the dark passage... The BEAM of the flashlight finds a DOOR. A glint off meta At the door handle, a large PADLOCK, smashed open. Kathy darts the beam over the other TWO DOORS... both equipped PADLOCKS. Smashed. Kathy pushes through the first door into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy's flashlight over: Hanging BEDSHEETS separate the r into cubicles. Putrid mattresses. Condoms on the floor. Her eye catches MARKINGS UNDER A MATTRESS. She pulls it a And sees GIRLS' NAMES scratched into the floor... Under e name, etched in, a list of amounts: 50, 100, 30, 200, 20. Some kind of RECORD. Kathy PULLS back other mattresses. Dust. Some FAMILY PHOT And... a ragged PIECE OF PAPER: Crude drawings of sexual positions. A NUMBER by each one: $20, $30, $50, $100, $20 The amounts correspond exactly with the table on the floo Kathy looks around, sickened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down Community Center nestled in a shabby area outs the city. It's completely unassuming. From the outside, y might think it was abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelter is a converted gymnasium. Peeling wallpaper. forgotten notices from before the war, postcards. Patchy linoleum curls at the edges. A soft hum. Voices in rooms Kathy can't see. She walks down the hall with MILENA, 40s Bosnian, down-to-earth, forthright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These girls are told they have been bought and must repay the debt. They are told an outrageous sum, thinking they'll be let go when they earn back that money. But they never are. Kathy stares at her, taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sex trafficking is one of the worst things to happen after this war. Milena hands over a medical report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya has a severe internal infection. The doctor found (reading) "intentionally placed foreign objects causing a disruption of the vaginal wall".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreign objects?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coins. She's not the first. Men can feel deficient paying for sex, so they find other ways to feel powerful. Milena pushes through a door. To a DARK HALLWAY... Hanging bulbs flicker intermittently. They walk. Avoiding dripping leaks in the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gave her Penicillin, but the doctor is worried there could be something more serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will he know? They pass an EATING AREA. TEEN GIRLS sit, pick at food, c smoke and flip through magazines. They are clean, but wea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately that's all we can do for her. We're just a volunteer organization. Kathy stares at the girls, the sheer number of them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if there are so many victims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost our funding because of those. ...She points at a basket of CONDOMS near the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the U.S. Department of State. They have their rules. I'll do anything to give these girls some protection. But the Department of State thinks "Condoms encourage prostitution." NGOs caught giving them out, no longer receive US funding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these girls aren't prostitutes. Milena shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't realize the cycle they start. If there are no condoms in the bars... They pass a ROOM DIVIDER. Seeing... MORE GIRLS. IN THEIR TEENS. All broken. And desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the guys want to find ways of avoiding STDs. AIDS. Their solution? Pay more for virgins... Kathy sees A GIRL sit in a corner. She couldn't be more t TEN YEARS OLD. She sits alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the traffickers bring more in. Younger and younger. Now it's a global industry. Simple economics. If there is demand, you supply. Milena opens a DOOR, revealing... INSIDE THE ROOM: A VOLUNTEER NURSE sits by Raya's bed. She lies asleep. IN ANOTHER BED: Irka sleeps. Kathy watches. Hushed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can they get help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the Global Displacement Agency. They have good medical care, lots of funding. They might take them. Whether they'll keep them or not... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the other girls from the Florida bar? Milena looks at her. Blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local police were bringing them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those girls never arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNMHQ stands over the crumbling red roofs of Sarajevo. In foreground, a CEMETERY packed with crooked wooden crosses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy walks in. Carmen sits behind a desk, piled with fil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you about it over a drink. Could you just check something for me? I want to get a copy of the monitor's report from a raid on the Florida Bar yesterday. Carmen nods, and clicks on her computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your job is so exciting. The only thing I get to raid is the fridge. (Reading off the computer)... You sure there was a raid? There's no record here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's definitely it. There were six girls removed from the bar and I need to know where they were taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. No record of any raid. Kathy thinking. Something's not adding up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy walks. MONITORS greet her as she passes. She reache OFFICE, and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Fred Murray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE local MEN in fatigues scan the field slowly with han held minesweepers. One MAN holds up his hand as his devic BEEPS. At the edge of the field, Fred Murray blows a whis Everybody else STOPS. The man bends down, as all wait... Kathy approaches from the road, behind a fence. Fred smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We meet again! Kathy looks out, suddenly aware of the dangerous situatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it okay for me to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. You're fine here on the gravel. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to follow up with you on the raid yesterday. Those girls didn't show up at the Shelter, and I wanted to locate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the whole thing was a bit of a mess. Turned out it was a local police mistake. Mix-up with the tip off or something. Thought they had a prostitution bust, but the bar is legit and those girls were just waitresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waitresses aren't kept under lock and key. ANOTHER WHISTLE BLOWS. Fred turns to the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Can we go over this later? I got to get in there. Before she can answer, Fred is moving down the field. She watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and Milena lead Raya and Irka out to her SUV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stark contrast, the GDA is a new and shining edifice. Kathy's SUV pulls up front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and the girls sit in the waiting area. The place is modern, western... corporate. In platinum base relief ove the reception desk: GLOBAL DISPLACEMENT AGENCY. The LOBBY. Magazines on a coffee table. The wall adorned a HUGE FRAMED POSTER of a young girl in a spiderweb. A caption: "TRAFFIKU ZHINOK YE SPRAV. 1999" Kathy scans the hall. Endless posters. 1998, 1997, 1996.. LAURA LEVIN, 30s, American, groomed, business-like, comes around the corner. Her ASSISTANT, 20s, leads the girls aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy. The new Head of Gender Affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard. Laura Levin. My assistant will take them to the medical center. As soon as they get medical clearance we'll know where we stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's yet to be determined if they'll cooperate with the repatriation program. That's the only way I can allow them to stay at the GDA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're critical... witnesses for a situation I'm... monitoring. I'll need to speak with them when they're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be contacting their parents? Laura nods. Something still on Kathy's mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other girls from the raid were supposed to go to the Women's Medica Shelter, but they never showed up. Do you have any idea where else they might have been taken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know there were any others. Kathy eyes the girls down the hall. Raya turns, a last lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy starts her car. She pulls out, turning left. Then, cranks the wheel right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy's UN SUV swerves along the serpentine mountain road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura in her office. HIGH MODERNITY. She works through he files. Opening one with Raya's photo on top. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone is ringing. Halyna rushes to it. Out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kochan, I'm calling from the Global Displacement Agency in Sarajevo to confirm you have a daughter named Rayisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Straightening) Yes. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have located her... Halyna falls into a chair, her chest heaving relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy pulls up to a PARKING LOT full of CARS and UN SUVs. MUSIC spills out. BACK IN BUSINESS. She gets out of the S moving inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy in the doorway. The place is dark but lit by lamps along the walls. MUSIC pumps. The place is hopping. A scantily-clad GIRL dances on the stage, her body writhing her eyes dead. Along the edges, girls - the very SAME GIR Kathy saw released at the raid - 'socialize' with custome Many of the CUSTOMERS... in IPTF UNIFORMS, others with of duty IPTF SWEATSHIRTS, and INTERNATIONALS in civilian casuals. A few LOCALS at the bar, where... Tanjo commands the scene, cheery, chatting with an IPTF OFFICER at the bar. Kathy stands, frozen , until she catches the eye of... Luba, sitting on the knee of a MIDDLE-AGED IPTF Officer. Kathy is filled with... anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy SPEEDS up the mountain roads. Past many bars. One a another, after another... All filled with UN SUVs. Groups drunk OFFICERS spill out. She stops across from one, seei Jan coming out of the bar. Kathy watches, stunned... Jan helps a drunk friend pile into an SUV. He looks up an sees Kathy as a car beam slides over her. She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stands on the balcony. Taking in the cold air. A KN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy, it's Jan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What's wrong? Kathy stands, quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me in. Please. Kathy waits a moment, breathing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy paces as Jan struggles for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you go up there, when you know what happens to these girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a good-bye party. I was--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're thirteen, fourteen, fifteen--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. If you let me finish, I got a call. Some friends needed a lift home because they got drunk. But hey lady, you better wake up! EVERYWHERE is a brothel. The coffee shop down the street. The post office. My corner store. That's how it is here. I'm not interested, and I try and stay in clean places. And if you don't believe me, then fuck you. He looks at her, hurt - He cares what she thinks. Kathy s this. Something she hasn't felt in so long... Needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I'm not okay. These girls... What are these guys thinking? She looks at him, fighting the urge to trust him. Jan bru a strand of hair from her face. She lets go. He pulls her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan and Kathy in front of her computer. They're on an IPT MESSAGE BOARD: Flashes of Various Posts: New Girl at the Berlin Bar; New Twelve Year-Old Pussy at the Old Grill. They scroll down dozens of posts. Kathy looks at Jan, sha by the banal malevolence of a boys club gone wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy watches Jan, asleep in her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog hangs low over the waking valley of Sarajevo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR signs off on a final examination of a now much healthier looking Raya. He smiles. She signs a form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura hovers in the background as Raya dials the phone. H face raw with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone in the hall rings. But no one is there to answe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halyna at the door. Zenia pales. O.S. A kettle whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman will be home soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make your tea. I'll be quick.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Zenia pours tea out of a chrome kettle. Her hands shake. Halyna stares at a new dishwasher. Then a microwave, blen and small LCD TV. Suspiciously out of context in Kyiv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roman seems to be doing well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to borrow money. Zenia looks up, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found Raya in Sarajevo. I want to go and get her. I don't need much. Zenia nods, keeping still as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he still hit you? Zenia chokes on her tea. Conflicted between love and guil She wants so badly to say... but she can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I hate to ask. But she's my daughter... and your niece. Please--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you the money... But you have to go. Roman will be home soon. He won't give it to me if he knows it's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy watches Rick flip through her report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred Murray. There were other officers too. But the raid was not in the books. These girls were just sent back. They are clearly not waitresses. They are victims. I think IPTF were paid off to turn a blind eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a serious allegation. And you don't have any evidence. I can't open an investigation based on a hunch. He drops the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna need more than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya and Irka sit across from Laura Levin. She slides a document over to each of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you sign here, you confirm that you are voluntarily entering the repatriation program at the GDA. Raya eyes Irka, confused. Laura softens slightly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This means we can get you out of Bosnia. Isn't that what you want? Raya's eyes widen. Irka is shocked, but joyous. They neve thought this moment would come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stay here for two weeks, to continue medical treatment as well as psychological counselling. We'll give you a ticket home and a stipend of $200 to get started when you return. Suddenly Irka's face drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... What do I do then? My parents were killed in Kosovo. It was my brother who sold me here... Can't I go somewhere else? Laura fumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can only send you home, but what you choose to do after that is up to you. But now, angry tears well in Raya's eyes. She looks up, t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the others, the girls in the bar. My friend Luba, we ran, she couldn't... I don't know where she is... I can't go without her. Please... Laura pauses, taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but my role here is to get you home. Otherwise you stay in Bosnia, where you... could face charges for illegal prostitution. Raya stares, reeling... To be made to feel like a crimina

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will sign. Raya looks at her, but Irka doesn't look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stares out across the central courtyard. Into the adjoining building. Through the glass, she watches... Fred Murray leading NEW RECRUITS through the halls. He jo around, as the OFFICERS eye him with respect. The PHONE RINGS. Kathy turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stands in disbelief. Laura is stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya and Irka could be key witnesses in a UN investigation. I thought we were all on the same team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irka can stay. But I can't keep Raya here. She is refusing to cooperate in the repatriation program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, just let her stay two weeks. Then we can take it from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We only house fourteen girls. It's a valuable spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks. If she's going to testify, she's not safe anywhere else. Laura shrugs, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits across from Raya. A TRANSLATOR to the side, translates as Raya speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were supposed to work in a hotel. (shaking her head) Now... I can be charged with prostitution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another option... I want to help you find your friends. But you need to help me do that. Kathy takes out the photo of Fred Murray and lays it on t table. Raya eyes it, defiant, no reason to trust her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of this is your fault. I want to go after the people who hurt you. But I need to know exactly what happens. As a witness in UN custody, you will be protected and will not be charged for any crimes. Raya stares, still not convinced.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: The translator starts. Raya stops her. Frustrated. Turnin Kathy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UN will protect me? They don't protect me when they drink in bar and fuck me and my friends. Kathy is humbled. She looks at Raya, open, raw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a daughter, just your age... I wouldn't stop until I found her. The two women stare at each other. A silent connection. R looks down, almost... ashamed. Struggling to get this out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only left because... there was nothing, no jobs, no... chances. I was good in school. But with no money... My mother... She is on her own. She works so hard. But nothing changes. I thought I could help her. He said we would work in a hotel. With good wages... Tears gathering in her eyes... It's terrifying to remembe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... When we got there... Other girls were there. Like us. From Ukraine, Moldova, Romania, everywhere... We were in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody could hear us... They... rape us... One girl go crazy, screaming... He shoots her. He shoots her right in the head. Then we was... sold. Like animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya is stopped by a rush of tears. Kathy reaches for her hand. Looking at this girl, so young... Raya looks Kathy squarely in the face. She slides the pho of Murray toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not the only one. They come every month. Tanjo give them money, so they don't raid the bar. That day you come... Tanjo did not want to pay. They want to punish him. Take his money. His girls. I ran...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raya sobs, knowing she has betrayed the system. Betting h life on the hope that this system won't betray her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milena leads Kathy through the halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get evidence. How many girls do you have here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least thirty five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits with GIRL after GIRL. Listening to their stori Writing furiously... Kathy interviews EVA, 16. She talks through grateful tear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Many of them come in. Uniforms like you. Different flags on the shoulders. I will testify. I don't care anymore. One brings cigarette. His name is Peter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy with a different girl, FADILA, 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sometimes if it's a party, a birthday, they pay for a group of girls, all together. Do whatever they want. Brian, the Irish guy, said Bosnia was better than Thailand for girls. Another girl, JASMILA, 18 - stunning, with haunted eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier from Italia say I was his girlfriend. I ask him to help me. But the bar owner pay him off. He has a tattoo of Tiger on his arm. Yet another, NADIA, 14, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paolo come every week. He had a thin moustache, the other...here I have a picture... Kathy wasn't expecting that. Nadia throws down a photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved the Firecracker. Nadia lifts up her sweatshirt, revealing a long scar. Kathy inspects the photo: Nadia with a SOUTH AMERICAN and U.S. IPTF: Their arms around her. One licks her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They burn me. Then they laugh. Kathy eyes Nadia... Silently in awe of her strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any more pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy pins Nadia's photo on a large bulletin board. Steps back. The wall is covered in photos of girls. Kathy reaches for the phone. Dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three in the morning, ma... I'm sleeping. Kathy sits back, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just was thinking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, can I go back to bed now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Of course, I just... It's great to hear your voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stands before Rick's desk. He smiles at her, conviv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy. I followed up on the Florida Bar. It's worse than I thought. There was a protection racket. IPTF... Americans, Romanians, were taking pay-offs to make sure the place wasn't busted. That raid was a punishment bust, because the owner stopped paying. But he must've settled it because the girls are right back where they started. Locked up in the hills. Rick scrambles for words, but Kathy's not finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to thirty five girls at the Shelter. All this testimony can't be ignored. Our guys are patronizing the bars in large numbers. Rick, serious abuses are taking place. It's all in my reports. Kathy lays her stack of files on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's back up a second here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got two girls ready to testify about IPTF taking pay-offs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testify where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bosnian court? Not gonna happen. All International Personnel have immunity. Kathy is stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But there must be some channel, some exception--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you've done really good work here. These are serious allegations. Let me look into how to handle it. I'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The markets shut down. The Catholic Church Bells ring. Ac the square the Call to Prayer echoes from old loudspeaker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan stirs a pan. Kathy awkwardly cuts vegetables beside h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different for us. We're all military or police. Every contingent except for the U.S... if someone does something wrong, they have to answer to a military tribunal at home. With the Americans... your Dyncorp guys? I don't think you have that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Americans aren't legally accountable for anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, I think our superiors would keep it quiet too. I mean, I haven't seen a military tribunal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan can't help noticing that Kathy is making a mess of th vegetables. He takes the knife. She walks away, preoccupi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my mission stay is up in a few weeks... You could come home with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what? She turns, glass of wine in hand, leaning on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just... This place, y'know, it gets to you. I'm, I'm worried what will happen to you a year from now. She puts down her glass of wine, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone does. She looks at him, seeing... It's not discouragement. It's love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Fred Murray could just walk up to a man and shoot him in daylight and he'd never see the inside of a courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Bosnia, yes... but... I mean, something that public could get him sent home. And tried in his own country. Kathy gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crumbling edifice, once home to the world's finest, now reminder of humanity's worst. INSIDE... Kathy walks with Madeleine, who unleashes Helen the hound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen loves it here. I think she has Olympic ambitions. Kathy hands Madeleine the files. She flips through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted these girls to testify in a trial against the IPTF officers. But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The immunity problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but if the girls testify in a Bosnian court against their trafficker... Tanjo... they'd have to mention what else goes on in the brothels. Madeleine nods. The dog comes bounding back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could work. If you make certain that in their testimony they mention every sordid detail of IPTF involvement--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is their testimony. Then it would be on record. Somebody would have to pay attention. Like...the State Department? Madeleine grins, proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna answer for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy weaves around the corner of a dimly lit, shabby hallway. She arrives at a doorway: VEHICLE DISPATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy talks to LEWIS, 20s, American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the two girls have to go to the hospital to get immunized, or they can't stay in the country. I need an armored security vehicle. Lewis looks at her, almost laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky you have a car at all. We're stretched to the limit. Besides, isn't this a local police matter? Try them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy parks her SUV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy walks into the station, drawing the attention of th LOCAL COPS. Danik rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for-- Danik turns away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viko... your American girlfriend is here! Kathy eyes Danik. Viko comes out, smiling broadly at Kath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and Viko walk out, energized with a sense of purpos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no problem. The Van is just sitting here. Let's go. They arrive at a POLICE VAN. Kathy eyes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not exactly armored, but it will do the trick. You follow me, yes? He jumps in, and starts it up. Kathy follows in her UN SU Across the street, a LOCAL MAN watches from INSIDE A CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy SWERVES up. Viko has the Van parked right up agains the door. Kathy jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura leads a very scared Raya out. Kathy smiles, gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Laura) Where's Irka? Laura takes a deep breath, eyeing Raya...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to have a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy looks at her watch -- at Raya. Viko taps her should VIKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take her. Meet us when you're done. As Viko and Raya leave, Kathy stops her... KATHY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right behind you. Are you okay? Raya nods, trusting in Kathy. Who turns, angry, back to.. LAURA LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to call you. There was a problem. During our repatriation procedures, we realized Irka had no passport. KATHY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we get her one. Where is she? LAURA LEVIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get it. She was trafficked from Belgrade. Her parents were killed in Kosovo. And she has no documentation. No embassy will recognize her. She is a girl without a country. KATHY
